intro: Elephantopus liatroides, commonly known as the hairy false dandelion, is a flowering plant native to tropical and subtropical regions of Africa, Asia, and Australia. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and opposite, hairy leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with slender stems and lobed leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. Its flowers are yellow and appear in clusters, producing small achenes that are dispersed by the wind. It thrives in moist, disturbed soils and is often found in open woodland or along riverbanks.
